body: Never mind. Nullable support for Map and Array type seems to be missing. Addressed to 44573cc.
Super, thanks @julianhyde !
Looks like travis failed in the calcite core build (the avatica portion was fine), so I'll just go ahead with this one.
I did a quick review and it all looks good, but can you please add some tests?
@julianhyde OK. I'll add relevant tests and mention you. Thanks for guiding!
Even better, add a comment to the jira case.

Might any of your fine folks (@julianhyde, @F21, @minji-kim) have a chance to take a look at this?
- The present avatica artifact (g:org.apache.calcite.avatica, a:avatica) has not changed; it is still the shaded avatica "client" jar. There is a new artifact (g:org.apache.calcite.avatica, a:avatica-core) which is just our Avatica client code (the core module in Avatica). tl;dr old users dont' have to change their Maven GAVs for our artifacts unless they want to use the new unshaded jar we'll publish.
- L&N inside the jars is correct (best as I can tell)
- Jackson is now relocated in the (shaded) avatica-$VERSION.jar
- Tested Avatica with protobuf and json using the shaded jar using the standalone HSQLDB server artifact
- Added documentation explaining how users build their own artifacts using this unshaded avatica-core-$VERSION.jar 

Anything I missed?
Has been partially fixed in 92e6494, and what's left is covered by https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/CALCITE-1361.

Please have a look at `testAccessNestedMapWithANYTypeWithoutCAST`. 

SqlFunctions.eq() only provides two overloaded signatures, (Object, Object) and (BigDecimal, BigDecimal). But there could be another case (Object, BigDecimal) when left operand is Object (type information is not provided) and right operand is primitive type.
(actually it throws exception complaining there's no SqlFunctions.eq(Object, int) so we might need to convert operands if needed.)

Is it better to handle this case to make life easier as well, or we want to respect strict type? If you agree to handle this, I'll handle this from another issue.

I've seen those problems before - with all the combinations of null and not-null values (e.g. `eq(int, int)`, `eq(Integer, int)`, `eq(int, Integer)`, `eq(Integer, Integer)`). I realized that I couldn't create a method for each combination; I had to solve it with code generation. I think your problem is very similar.

In https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/CALCITE-1054, I take a radical approach to null handling: check for nulls first, then later assume that the value is not null and can be converted to a primitive. I got quite far - see the PR attached to that case - but never quite got it committed. I still think it's a very worthwhile approach. The same approach could be applied to dynamic typing, I think. Can you take a look at the PR and see whether it would work?
@HeartSaVioR, In CsvTest.testJson, why did you add a WHERE clause?
@julianhyde CsvTest.testJson was a quick test fix before adding unit test on core. I'll revert it.
@julianhyde And yes, I'll take a look at it. Btw, I think we can handle it as separate issue.
OK. Got it back.

Yes, let's treat .eq as a separate issue. There's enough in this PR already!

I have a question about `testNestedArrayOutOfBoundAccess`. You go with PostgreSQL's semantics (return null) rather than standard SQL (throw an exception). I'd prefer to go with the standard behavior, and return null only if enabled by a `Conformance` setting. Do you agree?

And by the way, I can't see which code you changed to get rid of the ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException. What did you change?

Ah, it seems that you didn't make `arrayItem` any worse. Let's leave it for now, then. Can you log a JIRA case that the current behavior is wrong?

I just pushed a branch with my fix-ups to your edit, https://github.com/julianhyde/calcite/tree/1386-item. Let me know if my changes are OK; if so I'll squash and commit.
I'll file an issue for that. Btw, I left comment on your fix. NullPolicy of ITEM should be ANY even if we follow standard SQL.
Other than it looks great. Thanks for clearing up, @julianhyde.

Filed https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/CALCITE-1401.

Btw, if you want to make a whole conversation from JIRA issue because of the rule of Apache Project (historical data should be stored to Apache infra, AFAIK), I'm OK to move on.

@F21 Is there a way to disable Travis without deleting .travis.yml? This would be easier to go back to running on travis (hypothetically) without trying to find the old file in history.
@joshelser Good idea. You can disable it in the `Integrations and services` tab in the repo settings. I will restore the file and rebase.
Ok, `travis.yml` has been restored and the branch has been rebased. To set up wercker, someone with write access to the repo will need to add the app on the wercker website.

> To set up wercker, someone with write access to the repo will need to add the app on the wercker website.

That would have to be a request to the ASF INFRA team. They're the only ones with administrative privileges to access the repositories on Github. Filing a JIRA issue in the INFRA project is one way or you can shoot them an email at infrastructure@apache.org. Sending an email might be best and then you can also cc dev@calcite.
@joshelser Thanks for the pointers. I've sent a request off to the INFRA team

The INFRA team just replied that they are unable to set up Wercker because it will need write access to the repo. How was travis originally setup? I can see that it builds under the apache namespace: https://travis-ci.org/apache/calcite/

> The INFRA team just replied that they are unable to set up Wercker because it will need write access to the repo

Ahh that's a bummer. I didn't realize it would need write access. The reasoning is very long-winded if they weren't clear, but, in short, that's definitely not going to happen.

> How was travis originally setup? I can see that it builds under the apache namespace:

Maybe travis doesn't require write access to the repo? Not sure.
Oh, it looks like I also missed the non test-jar dependency. I will fix that along with your change here.
In this case, I think this PR should be closed. Let's try and get ASFBot to build PRs using the ASF jenkins instance and continue the discussion in the relevant JIRAs.

It depends which phase the error occurs in. SqlValidatorTest, SqlToRelConverterTest, RelOptRulesTest are good places for validator, converter, and planner tests. Log a JIRA case with the error stack and that will give me a better idea how to reproduce it.

I'm not sure what to do about that

There was one mistake in SortJoinTransposeRule change, and after correcting the mistake I found out that testSortTransposeRule6() didn't work as expected. That was because the uniqueness of mock tables was implemented. Adding uniqueness implementation will break a few tests mostly in RelOptRuleTest. So I'll close this PR for now and fix those broken tests' ref.

Note: [edc28ad] resolves a strange problem that i unintentionally  have caused. Apparently we need to keep the `connection` and `statement` open after the `execute(sql)`. By setting their fields to `null` we prevent the `final` block from closing them.

AggregateFilterTransposeRule and AggregateJoinTransposeRule will bail out for already unique group keys, so adding unique keys to some mock tables will prevent these rules being fired in a few test cases in RelOptRuleTest. Also change of uniqueness will affect row count number in RelMetadataTest. So I made some adjustment to the affected tests by replacing unique key columns with non-unique key columns.

@joshelser I guess the real question is whether offsets past Integer.MAX_VALUE are supposed to work or not. I raised this patch because the surrounding code suggests offsets past Integer.MAX_VALUE are supposed to work: the field in Meta.Frame is `public final long offset`, and also Meta.fetch() takes a long offset. So in that case this constructor should also take a long.

If offsets past Integer.MAX_VALUE are not supposed to work, then this patch isn't accomplishing much. But then it's misleading for the offsets in Meta.Frame and Meta.fetch() to be longs rather than ints.

> I raised this patch because the surrounding code suggests offsets past Integer.MAX_VALUE are supposed to work: the field in Meta.Frame is public final long offset, and also Meta.fetch() takes a long offset. So in that case this constructor should also take a long.

Gotcha. Thanks, I didn't notice that when I glanced at the patch.

Our general convention definitely states that we match what JDBC does, but I'm fine with making the Frame POJO consistent and we can revisit that inconsistency later in the future. If you have a moment, @gianm, a comment acknowledging this inconsistency would be fantastic.

Julian might have some more to add as he's been working with JDBC a bit longer than I have ;)

Sorry, @julianhyde, for leaving this PR open without giving any update. So after CALCITE-1500, setting the "original" root has been moved to Programs.standard(), which means there is an option now for the user not to set this particular rel as the root by overwriting this Program. But it is not the default behavior of Calcite yet, coz in CALCITE-1500 I was only trying to solve the decoupling of materialization substitution and to keep the original workflow intact.
That said, I will close this PR and will create a new one at some point, maybe after CALCITE-1536 is complete, coz that way we can create a new planner each time we need to in the new workflow of the "standard" Program.
@julianhyde yes

@julianhyde i think the it is ready still can not figure out a way to ITest this because the Calcite Query execution does re-write the IN to an OR so can't get to the branch i want. Can you suggest a way to tweak the query engine used or disable that rule just for ITest ?

Calcite `RexCall`s do not use IN. The only fix I can see for this issue is to expand `x IN  (a, b, c)` to `x = a OR x = b OR x = c` while converting to RexNode.

If it's really important that you generate IN in Druid queries, you'll need to write some logic that converts ORs back to IN. But I wouldn't be surprised if Druid sargs its expressions.
Closing, because it breaks backwards compatibility.

@julianhyde, this PR is in a good shape: tests and checkstyle checks pass. After your suggestion on the [Jira](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/CALCITE-1598?focusedCommentId=15840763&page=com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.issuetabpanels:comment-tabpanel#comment-15840763), I have added a _PigSchema_, _PigToEnumerableConverter_ and associated classes in order to support Calcite SQL by the Pig adapter. Test cases in _PigAdapterTest_ show that the flow from SQL to Pig-specific relational expression trees to Pig scripts is now supported.

The big piece that is currently missing is actually executing Pig scripts and returning results via Calcite. I am working on that now, initially supporting Pig's local execution mode. Getting close. I'll leave it up to you to make the call on whether or not you want to check it into version 1.12 without this functionality.

Other limitations of the existing Pig adapter impl:
- Only supports VARCHAR columns. Need more data type support.
- Filters are not pushed to be before joins. To be investigated.
- Need expansion of supported functionality and test coverage for more permutations of filters, aggregations and joins.

The DruidAdapterIT tests don't get run unless you have a https://github.com/vlsi/calcite-test-dataset VM running.

We don't require committers to run integration tests for every commit. Usually we're OK - but in this case we're not.

On the server where I run tests, the mere fact that the VM is running seems to make it more likely that a test run will seg-fault, so I've been less inclined to run it recently.
